plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: Dahlias are tuberous plants known for their vibrant, multi-petaled flowers that come in a broad spectrum of colors. They bloom in late summer to early autumn, making them a favorite ornamental garden plant.
plants.location: Native to Mexico and Central America; cultivated worldwide in temperate climates
plants.funFact: Dahlias were declared the national flower of Mexico in 1963 due to their cultural significance and striking beauty.

plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy wildflower with bright yellow petals surrounding a dark brown central cone. It is a symbol of encouragement and motivation in North America and often blooms in late summer through fall.
plants.location: Native to North America, commonly found in meadows and along roadsides
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are known to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, supporting ecological health.

plants.name: Erica carnea
plants.description: An evergreen shrub that produces profuse small bell-shaped flowers, often appearing as early as late winter but in some climates can continue blooming into early autumn, especially cultivars adapted to temperate zones.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring, some lasting into early autumn in mild climates
plants.location: Native to alpine regions of central and southern Europe
plants.funFact: Erica carnea can bloom through snow and frost, making it a unique early or late bloomer depending on climate.

plants.name: Helianthus annuus
plants.description: Sunflowers are tall, sturdy plants with large flower heads composed of bright yellow ray florets and a central disc. They bloom in late summer to early autumn and are widely cultivated for seeds and oil production.
plants.bloomingSeason: July to September (sometimes extending into October)
plants.location: Native to North America; widely cultivated globally
plants.funFact: Sunflowers exhibit heliotropism, turning to face the sun during the day, optimizing photosynthesis.
